mentions.context: Our NArabizi treebank contains 5 annotations layers: (i) tokenization, (ii) morphology, (iii) codeswitching identification, (iv) syntax and (v) translation.

As the NArabizi treebank contains more than 36% of French words, it is of interest to use recent methods of visualization to see how interleaved it is with some of its source languages.

Unlike NArabizi dialects, the resource situation for Arabic dialects in canonical written form can hardly be qualified as scarce given the amount of resources produced by the Linguistic Data Consortium regarding these languages, see (Diab et al., 2013) for details on those corpora.
Since the PADT corpus is a collection of MSA sentences with no diacritics, it is impossible to directly "transliterate" into NArabizi.
Using the Farasa software (Abdelali et al., 2016), PADT sentences are diacritized with 81% precision rate, 9 then tokens aligned with corresponding diacritized words.

We trained the UDPipe parser (Straka and Straková, 2017) on various treebanks obtained by combining different proportions of the French GSD and our PADT-based pseudo-Arabizi treebank.
The trouble with NArabizi is that it is a spoken language whose presence can be mostly found in informal texts such as social media.
As stated before, NArabizi takes its root in Classical Arabic and in multiple sources of integration of French, MSA and Berber, the Amazigh language.
A typical example of NArabizi that also exhibits code-switching with nonstandard French spelling can be seen in Example 1.
From now on, we will call NArabizi the Algerian dialect of Arabic when written in Arabizi, thereby simultaneously referring to the language variety and to the script itself.

Since we are only interested in NArabizi, we designed a classifier to extract proper sentences from that raw corpus.
As stated earlier in this paper, NArabizi contains a high-level of code-switching with French and is closely related to MSA.
5,794 sentences were classified as NArabizi by the Fasttext model and not SVM.
The baseline POS tagger we used is alVWTagger,11 a feature-based statistical POS tagger, which ranked 3rd at the 2017 CoNLL multilingual parsing shared task (Zeman et al., 2017).
Given the large number of noisy data in Com-monCrawl, a "noise" class is added to the language classification model and is built according to several heuristics.

As other North-African Arabic dialects, NArabizi is a resource-poor language, with, to the best of our knowledge, only one available corpus developed by Cotterell et al. (2014) for language identification purposes.
We therefore manually annotated 300 more NArabizi sentences (Arabizi train300 ), to be used as additional training data.
These 1500 sentences form the core of our NArabizi treebank annotation project.
Before it can be used as training data, the PADT needs to first be transformed into a form similar to NArabizi.
Given the large number of noisy data in Com-monCrawl, a "noise" class is added to the language classification model and is built according to several heuristics.
As vowels are always written in Arabizi, the PADT corpus needs to be diacritized before transliteration.
Using the Farasa software (Abdelali et al., 2016), PADT sentences are diacritized with 81% precision rate, 9 then tokens aligned with corresponding diacritized words.
Note that we performed a set of baseline experiments with UDPipe 2.0(Straka and Straková, 2017) as well on a previous version of this data set.
Given the large degree of interleaving between French and NArabizi, it is interesting to assess the impact of the French vocabulary on the performance of a POS-tagger trained on French data only.
In order to perform a meaningful evaluation, we split the NArabizi training set into 4 buckets of approximately 25% of it size in tokens, with a increasing proportion of identified NArabizi tokens.

It turned out that training UDPipe on these 300 manually annotated NArabizi sentences only (Arabizi train300 ) produced better scores, resulting in a parser that we did use as a pre-annotation tool in a constant bootstrap process to speed up the annotation of the remaining sentences.
The objectives of this method are twofold: (i) selecting data from CommonCrawl using a neural classifier and (ii) using this data set to intersect the data collected with the previous method.

In order to ensure that the collected corpus contains as little non-NArabizi data as possible, we only release the intersection of the data we classified, to which we add the original NArabizi corpus (Cotterell et al., 2014) (after having removed the annotated data we extracted from it).
Our corpora are freely available 14 under the CC-BY-SA license and the NArabizi treebank is also released as part of the Universal Dependencies project.
The corpus we used as gold standard is made of 9k sentences of attested NArabizi from our original corpus and 18k of French and English tweets.
Among them, by random sampling, it can be stated approximately that 55% are indeed NArabizi.
This suggests that low-resource languages with a highlevel of code-switching such as NArabizi can benefit from NLP models trained on the secondary language.
Due to computing power limitation, we were not able to run our selection on the whole CommonCrawl.

In addition to the annotated data, we provide around 1 million tokens (over 46k sentences) of unlabeled NArabizi content, resulting in the largest dataset available for this dialect.

7 To evaluate the quality of the resulting data set, we randomly picked 3 times 100 sentences, and genuine NArabizi sentences were manually identified, which allowed us to assess the accuracy of our corpus as reaching 97%.
We introduced the first treebank for an Arabic dialect spoken in North-Africa and written in romanized form, NArabizi.

Arabic letters are either consonant sounds or long vowels, each one may have several different transliterations in NArabizi, depending on the writer's age, accent, education and first learned Western language.

To this end, we extract words embeddings using fastText (Joulin et al., 2016) from a corpus made of the "translitterated" PADT described in Section 5, the French UD GSD and NArabizi original corpus (Cotterell et al., 2014).

We then trained a classifier using Fasttext (Joulin et al., 2016) on 102 languages, 40k sentences each, extracted from the CommonCrawl-based, languageclassifed OSCAR corpus, to which we added the 9k sentences of the NArabizi original corpus and the "noise" class.

A probability must be assigned for each possibility, and to make it as close as possible to what is produced by NArabizi speakers, a small parallel corpus of PADT sentences and their transliteration 9 Other diacritization systems have better performances (Belinkov and Glass, 2015) but are either not maintained with the proper python packages, or come with a fee.

In order to make our corpus usable by modern, resource-hungry natural language processing techniques, we also used data-driven language identification models to extract NArabizi samples among the whole collection of the Common-Crawl-based OSCAR corpora (Ortiz Suárez et al., 2019) as well as 2 millions sentences of additional crawled webdata, resulting in 50k NArabizi sentences of high quality, to date the largest corpus of this language.

To this end, we extract words embeddings using fastText (Joulin et al., 2016) from a corpus made of the "translitterated" PADT described in Section 5, the French UD GSD and NArabizi original corpus (Cotterell et al., 2014).

Note that instead of adding lemmas, we included French glosses for two reasons: firstly for practical reasons, as they helped manual corrections done by non-native speakers of NArabizi, and secondly because of the non-formalized nature of this language, which makes lemmatization very hard, almost akin to etymological research as in the case of garjouma/the throat which can either originate from French gorge or be of Amazigh root.

Between the two, there are Amazigh words (rak, mech), arabized French words (tomobile < French automobile), Arabic words whose Berber pronunciation has resulted in an unexpected NArabizi rendering (nta instead of expected enta 'you', mchit instead of expected machayt 'to go-2SING').
In order to perform a meaningful evaluation, we split the NArabizi training set into 4 buckets of approximately 25% of it size in tokens, with a increasing proportion of identified NArabizi tokens.

In order to ensure that the collected corpus contains as little non-NArabizi data as possible, we only release the intersection of the data we classified, to which we add the original NArabizi corpus (Cotterell et al., 2014) (after having removed the annotated data we extracted from it).

In short, it is a left-to-right tagger that relies on a set of carefully manually designed features, including features extracted from an external lexicon, when available, and a linear model trained using the Vowpal Wabbit framework.

We then trained a classifier using Fasttext (Joulin et al., 2016) on 102 languages, 40k sentences each, extracted from the CommonCrawl-based, languageclassifed OSCAR corpus, to which we added the 9k sentences of the NArabizi original corpus and the "noise" class.

In order to speed up the annotation process of our data, we decided to create a pre-annotation morphosyntactic and syntactic annotator trained on quasi-synthetic data obtained by "transliterating" a pre-existing Arabic (MSA) treebank, the Prague Arabic Dependency Treebank (PADT), into the NArabizi Latin script, together with data from the French GSD UD treebank.

In order to speed up the annotation process of our data, we decided to create a pre-annotation morphosyntactic and syntactic annotator trained on quasi-synthetic data obtained by "transliterating" a pre-existing Arabic (MSA) treebank, the Prague Arabic Dependency Treebank (PADT), into the NArabizi Latin script, together with data from the French GSD UD treebank.

Preliminary experiments showed promising initial results, but further analysis pointed out a high level of noise in this initial set, both in terms of erroneous language identification and on the amount of remnant ASCII artifacts that could not easily be removed without impacting the valid NArabizi sentences.

In order to make our corpus usable by modern, resource-hungry natural language processing techniques, we also used data-driven language identification models to extract NArabizi samples among the whole collection of the Common-Crawl-based OSCAR corpora (Ortiz Suárez et al., 2019) as well as 2 millions sentences of additional crawled webdata, resulting in 50k NArabizi sentences of high quality, to date the largest corpus of this language.
